questions.experimentContext: Two competing models explain how the Golgi apparatus maintains its structure during cell division in mammalian cells. Model 1: The Golgi fragments into small vesicles that are distributed between daughter cells and reassemble. Model 2: The Golgi is absorbed back into the ER during mitosis and re-emerges from ER exit sites after division. A researcher has access to: photoactivatable GFP-tagged Golgi markers, electron microscopy, live-cell imaging, and ER-specific fluorescent markers.
options: Photoactivate GFP-tagged Golgi resident enzyme in the Golgi during G2, then track the fluorescent signal through mitosis using live-cell imaging — if it colocalizes with ER markers during mitosis, Model 2 is supported; if it remains in discrete vesicles, Model 1 is supported
Fix cells at various stages of mitosis and perform electron microscopy to observe Golgi structure
Measure total Golgi enzyme activity in cell lysates before and after mitosis
Treat cells with nocodazole to block mitosis and observe whether the Golgi fragments
questions.explanation: Photoactivation of a Golgi-resident enzyme followed by live-cell imaging through mitosis provides the most direct, real-time evidence. By activating GFP fluorescence specifically in the Golgi during G2 phase, the researcher creates a pulse-labeled population of Golgi proteins. Tracking these through mitosis reveals their fate: if they disperse into an ER-like reticular pattern that colocalizes with ER markers (e.g., Sec61β), Model 2 is supported. If they remain in discrete puncta/vesicles that do not colocalize with ER markers, Model 1 is supported. Electron microscopy (A) provides structural snapshots but cannot distinguish Golgi-derived vesicles from ER in fragmented mitotic membranes. Enzyme activity assays (C) measure total protein but not localization. Nocodazole (D) blocks mitosis entirely, preventing the question from being addressed, and nocodazole itself disrupts Golgi structure (Golgi scatters into mini-stacks), confounding the results.

questions.question: Which additional experiment would most strengthen the conclusion that MRP1 specifically mediates resistance through drug efflux?
questions.experimentContext: A cancer cell line has developed resistance to doxorubicin (a chemotherapy drug). The researchers hypothesize that overexpression of a membrane transporter (MRP1, a member of the ABC transporter family) is responsible. They have shown by Western blot that MRP1 expression is 10-fold higher in resistant cells compared to sensitive cells. They have also shown that intracellular doxorubicin accumulation is 70% lower in resistant cells. The researchers want to prove that MRP1 is directly responsible for resistance.
options: Use siRNA to knock down MRP1 in resistant cells and measure whether doxorubicin accumulation and drug sensitivity are restored to levels comparable to parental sensitive cells
Perform immunofluorescence to confirm MRP1 localizes to the plasma membrane in resistant cells
Overexpress MRP1 in a completely different cell type to see if it becomes resistant to any drug
Perform a cell viability assay comparing sensitive and resistant cells at various doxorubicin concentrations
questions.explanation: siRNA knockdown of MRP1 in resistant cells is the strongest experiment because it directly tests the causal requirement for MRP1 in resistance. If reducing MRP1 expression restores doxorubicin accumulation and resensitizes cells to the drug, this provides direct evidence that MRP1 overexpression is causally responsible (not merely correlated with resistance). This is a loss-of-function experiment in the relevant cellular context. Cell viability assays (A) only characterize the resistance phenotype but don't prove MRP1's causal role. Overexpression in another cell type (C) tests sufficiency but in an artificial context — the different cell type may have confounding factors. Immunofluorescence (D) confirms localization but doesn't prove functional causation. The gold standard would combine knockdown (necessity) with rescue by re-expression of siRNA-resistant MRP1 construct, but among the given options, B is the most direct and informative.

questions.question: Based on the data, which conclusion about the cytoskeletal requirements for cell migration is best supported?
questions.dataContext:
Researchers performed a wound-healing (scratch) assay on epithelial monolayers under different drug treatments. Gap closure was measured as a percentage of the original wound width closed after 12 hours.

| Condition | Drug Treatment | Target | Gap Closure (%) |
|---|---|---|---|
| 1 (Control) | DMSO vehicle | None | 85 ± 5 |
| 2 | Cytochalasin D (2 μM) | Actin polymerization (barbed end) | 8 ± 3 |
| 3 | Latrunculin A (0.5 μM) | Actin monomers (sequesters G-actin) | 5 ± 2 |
| 4 | Nocodazole (10 μM) | Microtubules (depolymerization) | 35 ± 8 |
| 5 | Taxol (10 μM) | Microtubules (stabilization) | 30 ± 7 |
| 6 | Blebbistatin (50 μM) | Myosin II ATPase activity | 12 ± 4 |
| 7 | Y-27632 (10 μM) | ROCK kinase (Rho effector) | 40 ± 6 |

All drugs were added 30 minutes before wounding. Cell viability remained above 95% for all conditions at 12 hours.
options: Microtubules are more important than actin for cell migration because nocodazole reduces gap closure more than cytochalasin D
Actin polymerization and myosin II-based contractility are both essential for wound closure, while microtubule dynamics contribute to but are not absolutely required for directional migration
ROCK kinase inhibition has no effect on migration because Y-27632 still allows 40% gap closure
Taxol and nocodazole have identical effects, proving that microtubule stability is irrelevant to migration
questions.explanation: The data clearly demonstrate that actin is the primary cytoskeletal system required for cell migration. Both actin-disrupting drugs (cytochalasin D and latrunculin A) nearly abolish wound closure (8% and 5%), showing that actin polymerization is essential for lamellipodial protrusion at the leading edge. Blebbistatin (myosin II inhibitor) also severely impairs migration (12%), demonstrating that actomyosin contractility is required for cell body retraction during movement. Microtubule-disrupting drugs (nocodazole and taxol) reduce migration to ~30-35% but do not abolish it, indicating that microtubule dynamics contribute to directional persistence and polarity but are not absolutely essential for migration itself. ROCK inhibition (Y-27632, 40% closure) partially reduces migration because ROCK phosphorylates myosin light chain and regulates actomyosin contractility downstream of RhoA — a significant but not complete reduction. Option A misreads the data (actin disruption is more severe). Option C ignores that 40% is a significant reduction from 85%. Option D ignores that both drugs impair migration by ~50-60%, showing dynamics matter.
